comments.commentBody: Unions are weak because of global competition.  American labor is not needed in many corporations.  Unions could only have clout if they were as multi-national as corporations.  Management squeezes productivity from workers, sometimes by technology, sometimes by fear.   Workers don't get raises while executives get generous raises.

First of all, you progs keep making the mistake of refusing to see a human being as an economic, rather than moral entity.

You can never change the fact that flipping burgers for a living, or changing bedsheets in a hotel, is a position that can economically justify high wages!

Sure, you can make the argument that morally, they deserve a high wage. But the global labor market we all compete in does not care about that, only the marginal utility of a skill set.

Please for God's sake take an economic course.

Actually, the "marginal utility" of fast food and other service workers is being given away in a race to the bottom with competitors. Labor being only a part of the cost of delivery, it takes modest rises in prices to account for its value in the same level it was done in the '70s.

Make it a law, and all competitors are on the same playing ground.

AR - I suggest you repeat your econ course.

There are multiple sources for the fact that most people who receive welfare stop receiving it  within a short period of time. I don't think you can find a source that says otherwise. There are people who get trapped on welfare, but most people don't.

All of this is true. And Americans seem to like the situation. Republicans are currently leading the generic ballot by about five points, indicating support for candidates who promise to slash unemployment benefits, repeal labor laws and workplace protections, crush the remnants of organized labor, and generally depress wages in any way possible. They promise, most emphatically, to repeal the law that, for the first time ever, at least alleviates the terror of losing one's job by making health insurance available to everyone. This all seems to constitute a popular platform.

The disconnect makes liberals, including me, rub their eyes and smack their foreheads and turn to MSNBC and Krugman for any shred of affirmation and hope. But as I contemplate another season of registering voters and knocking on doors, I'm prepared to see voters once again get what they vote for. Please, no more columns patronizing and pitying them. They're adults. They do this to themselves.

About one third of Obama's stimulus was tax cuts, in an attempt -- that failed -- to get Republican support for his stimulus package. As to no objective test for effectiveness of the stimulus, true enough, but that's usually true for economic policies, and many including esp. Krugman argued it was inadequate before it even passed, so it's not like no one saw it coming. Millions of teachers who were kept on because of it lost their jobs when stimulus ran out, so right there we have a concrete effect of its ending. As to "the Chosen One," your fire is misdirected. Perhaps most of the commenters here don't carry water for Obama. But if you think about it, there does seem to be a political force in this country whose sole economic policy seems to be corporate welfare and tax giveaways to the rich. I wonder who they are?

In response to "Charles", your comments have nothing to do with this column, as far as I can tell. As for the unrelated point you are making, economics is an inexact science and judgments about what economic policies have or have not done are always a subjective matter. The only way to know whether Obama's policies worked, or did not, would be to go back to 2008 and try out the opposite. When you have accomplished that objective study, perhaps you could  post the results here.

Wow, a completely content-free comment! I knew if I read long enough I'd find the Holy Grail - and it's brimful of Tea.

The joy of this comment by Charles of Tecumseh, MI, is that it could be appended to any NYT op-ed essay regardless of author or content. It has nothing to do with anything Krugman wrote. You could cut and paste it on any other column and it would be just as (ir)relevant.

Dear sas,

Thank you for highlighting what Bob Walker expects to occur if current global fertility remains constant.

Population experts who singularly focus on population 'cluster bombs' are failing to see the "big picture." In some sense they are not seeing the forest because of their rigid focus on the trees. The mere idea of 27 billion people of Earth in 2100 must give rise to images of things like a gigantic bomb, but one that is larger and more powerful than any bomb ever conceived of, much less invented and detonated, by humans. This population bomb would be so colossal and destructive that it would cast the shadow of death over the entire surface of the Earth and end life as we know it, I suppose.

Always,

Steve

b fagan - (1) water vapour follow hydrological cycle; ocean temperature & carbon dioxide follow the long term natural variation; heat-island effect follow the urban conditions and not greenhouse gases;deforestation releases more carbon dioxide and at the same time creates dryness and heat; irrigated agriculture and water spread areas are increasing and thus creating cold-island effect -- this is not accounted in global warming trend; oceans are polluted with contaminants; so on. In addition to all these the natural variation in global temperature contributes to ups and downs in global temperature; prior 1957 the global temperature data showed high variations, etc.

b fagan - (2) -- I saw a report that states "Scientists from University of Toronto claim to have discovered a greenhouse gas that is 7,100 times more potent than carbon dioxide. Perfluorotributylamine or PFTBA stays in the atmosphere for long time and has a very high radiative efficiency making it a potentially high global warming gas. PFTBA can not be destroyed by any natural process and can remain in the atmosphere for around 500 years. PFTBA is a manmade chemical used for various applications in electronic equipment, electronic testing and as a heat transfer agent since the mid 20th century." If it is true then there is an urgent need to clarify the real relationship between carbon dioxide and global warming phenomena -- Is it a real relationship???

Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy

Obama's proposed most of the same, perfectly reasonable, Keynesian ideas for returning us to full employment over the last few years that Krugman himself has rightly advocated. But as Krugman would be the first to explain to you, chapter and verse, nothing could be more obvious than the fact that it has been the Republicans' plot in the House and the Senate to BLOCK economic and job recovery by creating huge, deliberate fiscal drags on economic growth during the worst downturn during the Depression. If you don't believe me and Krugman, believe the Republican chair of the Fed, Ben Bernanke, who's BEGGED the Republicans in Congress to do their job, which is to stimulate demand with government spending during a serious downturn. Bernanke's QE has been nothing more than desperation in the face of the grotesque Republican determination to hurt the ailing economy as much as possible. Bernanke's been a hero in significantly foiling the Republican plot with QE, but he couldn't create full recovery in terms of growth and employment with QE alone, and never thought he could. All he could do was bring us down to 7% unemployment and growth in the 3% range recently.

Hey, did you get all you were looking to get for X-mas? “Get”, that’s quite a word, it is for us in the developed world anyway. You know we all like getting, rich or poor. However, if we keep the pace of getting that we are on now, we ain’t gonna get much in the end, dead maybe.

Yeah, you better be thinking about it, all that getting. I mean, do you wanna be the last one on earth to get, think about it, 300 years of getting and you’d get the last get that puts us over the top and suddenly the world blows up. Would you wanna be that last getter? I sure wouldn't, if there’s a hell then that would be it, being the last getter.

So here’s what we do, quit getting, obviously. Yeah just give up the getting. Some food, water, clothing, shelter, ain’t that enough getting? I mean you’d stay alive wouldn't you? And look at it this way, there’d be enough gets left on the earth to last us a long time, heck, you can go to the dump and get all kinds of gets, we can do that for decades. You probably have hundreds of gets in your garage, your closet, your back yard…all that. Just poke around in that pile of gets, you’ll see you don’t need any more of them.

Yeah see we’re all pigs, we in the developed world that is. Even our bums are pigs. I mean they want to get just like the rest of us, and it’s the wanting that gets the getting going in the first place. Yeah, ya gotta quit wanting so much, even you bums. Oh well, probably ain’t gonna happen, I just hope I ain’t the last getter.

I have long held a love of wood.

I say that after a working life that was equal parts metals mining and petrochemistry.

But I am sitting in the heartland of the forest industries now, in a home full of wood furniture resting on hardwood floors.

I do not see a conflict with my last paying job before retirement, in which I worked on building ethylene oxide plants for production of plastics and paints. Nor with the decades spent in producing explosives for the mines.

We need all these things to build and maintain our modern civilization. We just need to use the renewable and non-renewable resources in the most appropriate manner.

"And if businesses can't sell their products, they can't make money " The thing is that businesses that ARE selling products aren't really making any money. JC Penny's and many other places are going under selling goods. The folks who are really making a "killing" are those who are selling PAPER--that is where the money is. Sub prime car loans bundled in economic WMDs. Banks and investment houses borrowing money from the FED for nearly zero interest, buying bonds and making 3% or more.
The problem of a labor-less society can be fixed, but first we have to admit that we don't want a lot of labor workers. The population is way too high for the jobs available and will get only worse in the future. There are too many people with their heads in the sand trying to foretell the future.
Government won't fix the problem because there is too much money involved: e.g. when their paychecks depend on them not fixing the problem, they won't fix it. We delude ourselves daily into thinking that someone will come along and fix this problem. It is fixable, but not by the current occupiers of government. They have absolutely NO incentive to do so. If they had the incentive , this would not be the subject of discussion now.
Sadly, I think the only fix will be a subject that nobody really wants to hear. The French found a way 200 years ago, and that will likely be the only real solution here. Since workers have no power, it will another kind of social power to fix the problem..

I think this has as much to do with the paradox of thrift as it applies to business as anything else. All business people want to maximize profits, and one way to do this is to beat down labor costs. But if labor doesn't have any money to spend on what businesses produce than businesses can't sell their products. And if businesses can't sell their products, they can't make money (or at least as much money). So all that the suppression of wages ultimately results in is less for everyone - employers and employees.

Enlightened self interest suggests that the owners of capital as a class make sure that workers have enough to buy the goods that the owners of capital are trying to sell. What's needed are more latter day Henry Fords. For all his faults Henry Ford realized that workers who made more money had more money to spend on the things that Henry For produced. Unfortunately however, it seems that most of today's moguls can't look beyond their own bottom lines.

Peano's space filling curve could also be built on the other tour but not both in the same curve.

See Peano curve, http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Peano_curve&oldid=540809029 (last visited Dec. 27, 2013).
